message:
Howdy geeks ..

I have been thinking about a good introductory paragraph entry to start with , but i wasn't satisfied with any of the entries i came up with so i decided not to waste your time and get straight to the point .. 

Am not sure if such a post fits in this group or not , but i will really appreciate ur help.

Currently am in the 3rd grade in the Faculty of Computers and information system - Assuit university , and i have been struggling for a while trying to determine what specific field should i focus on and what specific skills should i enhance to land a job ASAP (Which is at least as soon as i graduate).

I have already tried quite some stuff , Lead the first team to join the ACM-ACPC annual contest from my university , We did pretty well as no training was provided , We were totally self-dependent (We beat the AUC,GUC beginners team though , Am sure we could have done better).

Anyways i have also tried to get my hands dirty working with some technologies , developed some java desktop applications , did some Web-Development in native php also used some micro-frameworks and worked a lil with (codeigniter and laravel) , Thanks to Alaa as he truly helped me a lot.

Using technologies is fun when everything works out pretty well , but it's pretty boring compared to abstract problem solving , specially optimization problems and AI..

Currently am getting used to the .NET framework , Working on a timetabling software for my faculty's semester timetables , In which am learning new AI techniques that i wasn't familiar with before (Ant colony optimization - Genetic algorithms - Graph coloring etc .. ) and also learning more about the .NET framework and C# (as i have chosen it to be the language am using for developing application for the .NET framework) .

So the problem is i really almost got no clue about what are the requirements of current employers and what should i do to land a job more quickly , Specially landing a job that isn't boring that it's only about implementing stuff for a specific framework or platform with no much thinking or problem solving involved , it would be just about getting used to that specific technology and acquiring more knowledge about flaws that might occur and bugs/problems that might show up later , Which is quite boring i guess. 

I really want to describe the position where am currently standing right now so you guys could provide the most efficient tips , but i guess that won't be easy right , Also i don't want to waste your time anymore ..

So in a nutshell what do you guys think i should be doing for the next couple of years before graduating taking in consideration that i might want to land an internship next summer , Thanks A LOT in advance , I totally totally appreciate your help , Sorry again for wasting your time.

data.message:
Ahmed Ragab First thanks for the decent mention i really did noting it's all your buddy :)

The next to to get an internship in a sexy company like itworks or IBM those are the best for now.

Read more about design patterns, database enhancements and big data, code documentation,..... and lots of topics
awel lma ab2a fady mmkn nt-chat w a7kelak aktr in details

last thing...you're a talented developer keep your eyes to get a relocation offer to Europe that's the place to be ;)
Mohamed Alaa El Din what about a hangout to help those talented guys ;) ?!
Web development in ASP.NET is the most sought after technology in the current job market

Proud to be your  friend dudy :D 
Is it possible that we meet the following week? I have some advices that I think they help you :) 

Keep searching and the most important thing that I advise myself a lot, and it's helpful for you I think, keep going and don't get frustrated or bored at any point till you reach the "BEGIN" of your dream road. The climate which we live in now is extremely frustrating and boring and it may lead you to  give up and live as a normal employee with 1,000 or 2,000 E.P/month. 

I wait impatiently to meet you my friend ^_^

Once you finish step 1, i.e. you can develop web applications, do data driven stuff and some client side tricks (not necessarily MVC), then do SharePoint development (1 year web dev + EF for data), then do 1 year of SP. After that I suggest you keep your saw sharp in your spare time with some Python and do a some algoroithm courses on coursera, and make sure you speak and write english in at least intermeddiate level  (not the c.v. level you write for employers, the real one). Also keep listening to tech podcasts and reading tech journals. in 3 years after a few projects under your belt and some cool new buzzwords, apply for jobs in US and Australian companies and whether you make it or not in the exams keep going to gain more experience until you can work for a foriegn company overseas. Please note the companies here are mainly a weak imitation of what they have overseas. So 2-4 years is more than enough if you focus to make it to the real thing. Also, try to gain an understanding of Agile and working in small teams in an Agile environment. But what will make you really employable and help you keep a job is you productivity in a specific technology.

Apply for Msc Computer Science scholarships, in UK/ GErmany and if you can afford it, even go for paid learning in a foriegn Uni. Even if you come back to Egypt, the companies and managers just kneel to anything that is foreign. Possibly do some projects on oDesk on the side if you have the time, to gain some time management and customer facing expeience cause most companies don't give you that the first few years
Try to creat Tutorial videos of stuff you've learnt in the yotube, along with a blog, even in Arabic will make you look passionate and proactive
Codility.com is a great place to sharpen your coding skills and many foriegn companies use it as a first screening interview

Don't velieve what people tell you about being the best in teh world, they are at best hard workers with big egos :) Just foucs on learning and know that it requires no special talents to do what 99% of coding companies require, just plain old practice and make friends with your boss.

I think if we actually knwo that as developers we can work anyshere in the world this will increase the employer competition for the good resources and also it will opne up fields for us all over the world. The biggest problem I have seen making some very smart people unemployable or decrease their chances in the Intl job market is lack of language skills, specially English. If you can speak frensh btw and are mediocre technically or German you have a much higher chance of landing a tech job at a multinational than you do if you were a tech genuis with no language skills. Also try to build your own web site to showcase your skills especially if you are a front end guy.
And try to deliver sessions at UNI and put up the videos on youtube, learn to speak and express yourself and enjoy it
And if you don't have the ability to read long articles like me, you can watch videos on MSDN, or Courses in Coursera and Youtube has millions of tutorials
You don't need to have a Phd in something to be called an Expert, you just need to know enough to produce results and with time learn some workarounds

you not need any advice from me you can  advise me
 i respect your mind

Anothe cool tip, if you like a specific technology and find a prominent blogger, send them an email, they are usually very helpful and they usually have great advice for you. Don't bug them with a million emails, but keep a nice connection with them. You can also reach almost anyone within Microsoft or Google. Just look for their blogs. Look at the blog of the development team of the product you are following to know things early. Follow the international conference streams like the Agile conferences and MS tech conferences and Pycon.

There is a Psychological barrier you need to cross to work on multiple platforms, so watch lots of videos on how things work in the Linux world, "getting started PHP/ Python/ Django/ Ruby" if you see enough of them even if you don't practice it will break the psychological barrier that you can't work on other platforms. Of course that can be totally broken if you try the examples on a VM even just once.

Finally, in my humble experience, just listen to the podcasts and watch the videos in a couple of months, if you do this daily you will get the "feel" for where the world is going, while you keep your job ofcourse developing  normal websites that access databases till you get the big break :)3
